text.tspan: Database keys are essential attributes that uniquely identify records and establish relationships between tables.
This visual guide explains all key types, their properties, and use cases with comprehensive examples.
- For indexing and faster data retrieval
- Not allowed to have NULL values
- Can be used for alt. identification
- All parts must be used together
A primary key is one of the candidate keys chosen to uniquely identify
â€¢ The value of primary key can never be NULL
â€¢ The value must always be unique (no duplicates)
â€¢ The values cannot be changed (no updates)
â€¢ The value must be assigned when inserting a record
â€¢ A relation is allowed to have only one primary key
Example: In the Employee table, Emp_Id is the primary key
A super key is a combination of all possible attributes that can
uniquely identify rows (or tuples) in the given relation.
â€¢ Super key is a superset of a candidate key
â€¢ A table can have many super keys
â€¢ May have additional attributes not needed for unique identity
A candidate key is an attribute or set of attributes which can
â€¢ A minimal super key (no redundant attributes)
â€¢ Selected as the minimum attributes required for uniqueness
â€¢ Not allowed to have NULL values
â€¢ The set from which primary key can be selected
Out of all candidate keys, only one gets selected as primary key,
remaining keys are known as alternate keys.
â€¢ Has same uniqueness properties as primary key
â€¢ Can be used as secondary identifier
â€¢ Often used for alternate access paths to data
Since Emp_Id is the primary key, {Aadhar_No} and {Email_Id}
